Dear Ms. Boyer:
Attached is the Interim Inspection Report for the above referenced agency completed on
3/7/2024. Due to the violations of applicable licensing rules, a written corrective action plan
is required. The corrective action plan is due 15 days from the date of this letter and must
include the following:
• For any repeat violations, why the prior corrective action plan did not result in
compliance.
• How compliance with each citation will be achieved.
• Who is directly responsible for implementing the action steps in the corrective
action plan.
• Specific time frames for each citation as to when the correction will be completed
or implemented.
• How continuing compliance will be maintained once compliance is achieved.
• The signature of the responsible party and a date.
If you fail to submit an acceptable corrective action plan, disciplinary action may result.
Please review the enclosed documentation for accuracy and contact me with any
questions. In the event that I am not available, and you need to speak to someone
immediately, please contact the area manager Jessica VandenHeuvel at (616) 204-6992.
Sincerely,
Jennifer Pastorick, Licensing Consultant

III. DESCRIPTION OF FINDINGS
The agency is in compliance with all applicable rules and statutes except for the following:
CCI Rule 400.4113 Employee records.
(1) An institution shall maintain employee records for
each employee and shall include documentation of all of
the following information prior to employment or at the
time specified in this rule:
(j) A written evaluation of the employee’s performance
within 30 days of the completion of the probationary
period or within 180 days, whichever is less, and a
written evaluation of the employee’s performance
annually thereafter.
One of three employee files reviewed requiring an annual evaluation was late by
fifteen days.
2

CCI Rule 400.4155 Institutions not detention institutions or shelter care
institutions; initial treatment plan
(2) The initial treatment plan developed by the social
worker shall document input from the resident, the
resident’s parents, direct care staff, and the referral
source, unless documented as inappropriate.
Two of three youth files reviewed lacked documented input from direct care staff
and referral source in the initial treatment plan.
CCI Rule 400.4156 Institutions not detention institutions or shelter care
institutions; updated treatment plan
(2) The updated treatment plan developed by the social
worker shall document input from the resident, the
resident’s parents, direct care staff, and the referral
source, unless documented as inappropriate.
One of one youth files reviewed having an updated service plan lacked
documented input from direct care staff and referral source in the updated
treatment plan.
IV. TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE
The agency was offered technical assistance in the following areas:
• Provided technical assistance regarding CCI Rule 400.4155 (d) and (e) regarding
ensuring initial treatment plan include indicators of goal achievement and the
person responsible for coordinating and implementing the youth and family
treatment goals as per the initial treatment plans reviewed the youth was indicated
as the person responsible. Provided technical assistance on other individuals that
would be responsible as well as including indications to show the goal is being
achieved based on specific behaviors/indications.
V. CONSULTATION
The agency was offered consultation in the following areas:
• Consultation provided on tracking annual employee performance evaluations from
the date the performance evaluation was reviewed and signed by the employee.
• Consultation provided on providing youth with additional towel and wash cloth per
youth request.
• Consultation on providing contracted teachers with pre-service learning if the
teachers have in-service days as the facility recently has a new teacher providing
service who is not familiar with the youth being served.
3

VI. EVALUATION OF RENEWAL PERIOD
Maltreatment in Care
There were no substantiated incidents of maltreatment in care during this licensing
period.
Corrective Action Plan Compliance
The agency has submitted 1 acceptable corrective action plans (CAP) during this
licensing period, and compliance with each individual CAP is as follows:
The agency has submitted 1 acceptable corrective action plans (CAP) during this
licensing period, and compliance with each individual CAP is as follows: The CAP
was in response to the 2023 Renewal Inspection dated 3/28/2023 where the facility
was found in non-compliance for rules 400.4147 (2) Dental Care, 400.4109 (1) (c)
Program Statement regarding Handle with Care training not being completed every
six months, and RFCJJ 2.11 Reentry/Aftercare Services (1) (d) ii. A CAP was
approved on 4/3/2023 and was effective as those violation was not a repeat during
this inspection.
Financial Overview
Teaching Family Homes annual third-party audit report for fiscal year ending
September 30, 2022, was reviewed by the Bureau of Audit. The audit report
included financial concerns however the concerns are improving. Net assets
indicate the extent to which revenues exceed expensed and is an indicator of the
financial health of an organization. The agency has a deficit in total net assets in
the negative, however this has improved from the previous year audit. The facility
has a working capital in the negative, which indicates an agency's inability to pay
off its short-term liability if they came due immediately, however this too has
improved from the previous year audit. The facilities financial condition will continue
to be monitored in subsequent audits, however there is improvement in this fiscal
year's financial audit.
Teaching Family Homes annual third-party audit report for fiscal year ending
September 30, 2023, is currently in draft status and not finalized.
PREA compliance (if applicable)
PREA Facility Audit Final Report dated 10/11/2023 was reviewed and the facility
was found in compliance.
Chief Administrator Assessment
4

Chief Administrator reported continued barriers regarding dentals for youth
following COVID 19. The facility has been requesting youth's last dental
documentation as part of the intake process to allow for more time to be able to
schedule youth dentals due to the dental provider scheduling several months out.
This has been helpful as it allows the facility a larger window to be able to schedule
and complete dentals to be in compliance with the licensing rules. The facility will
also be contracting with Smiles on Wheels to provide on-site, routine dental care
every six month to youth placed in the facility. This is tentatively planned to begin
June 2024. Chief Administrator also indicated barriers regarding obtaining qualified
staff in the area. The facility continues to post job opportunities on Indeed however
has not had many applicants and the applicants they have received do not return
calls and follow through with the interview/hiring process.
Staff and Youth Interviews
Three employees were interviewed during the onsite visit. All staff reported feeling
safe and supported in their job duties. The facility is short staffed however staff
continue to work at ensuring coverage as needed. The facility is actively hiring
however due to the location, the facility has continued to have difficulty finding
appropriate applicants. There were no concerns noted by staff.
Three youth were interviewed during onsite visit. The youth interviewed reported
feeling safe, feeling respected, and treated well by staff. All youth are attending
school onsite at the facility and receiving therapy twice a week. Youth reported
receiving three meals a day and snacks.
Description of Agency Walk Through
A walk through of the facility was completed during the onsite visit. The facility was
clean, and no safety concerns were noted. Medications and cleaning chemicals are
stored appropriately per licensing requirements. All bedrooms were viewed to have
appropriate bedding. The kitchen was clean with the menu posted on the
refrigerator. The facility had emergency plans posted and the intent to check
criminal history posted in the entry of the facility.
VII. RECOMMENDATION
Based on inspection findings the agency is not in compliance with all applicable licensing
statutes and rules. Upon receipt of an acceptable corrective action plan, it is
recommended that the agency continue on their regular license.
